comments:
I am trying to create a custom compiler error parser.  I create a class that 
extends AbstractUIPlugin and implements IErrorParser.  I then insert the 
following code to create an extension:

  <extension
         id="MyCompilerErrorParser"
         name="My Compiler Error Parser"
         point="org.eclipse.cdt.core.ErrorParser">
      <errorparser
            class="org.eclipse.cdt.internal.errorparsers.CompilerErrorParser">
      </errorparser>
   </extension>

When I debug the plugin I can step into the constructor and the start() and 
stop() methods, but never reach the "public boolean processLine(String line, 
ErrorParserManager eoParser)" method.  Everything I've researched and heard says 
that the plugin should make it there.

Thanks in advance!
Hurai

Ok, after more work on this... I am able to get the error parser to work, and 
the processLine(...) method is finally called, but as a side-effect I get an 
exception thrown.

In all of the examples I've seen, they extend AbstractUIPlugin and then the 
constructor looks something like this: 

public CompilerErrorParser(IPluginDescriptor descriptor) {
    super(descriptor); 
    plugin = this;
}

So what I did to get the class to work, was to change the declaration so that it 
extends Plugin and then changed the constructor to be empty (no arguments).  Now 
the parser is in fact called, but the exception is as follows (look at the 
bottom of this page).  Basically it all boils down to the fact that the class is 
missing the constructor that takes an IPluginDescriptor as an argument.  Very 
confusing, but I have a feeling the solution is close.
